titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. Dull weather. writing through most of the forenoon. Walk in the wood. Evening at Mr: Schimmelpenninck’s. Large company. Cards.— Quadrill with Mlle: Bicker, Mr: Vos de Steenwyk, and a Lady unknown. The Sterility of my Journal is in some measure owing to my Correspondences. My Letter books contain the most essential parts of my daily transactions.
2. Writing, the principal part of the day. Walk in the afternoon, beyond Ryswick. Evening at Mr: Noël’s party.— Cards and Quadrill.

3. Days pass in perfect uniformity. Visit from the Baron de Bonstettin. Letter to the Secretary of State. Evening at a Concert: subscription at the invitation of Mr: Goldberg’s. Performance dull. Company not numerous.— Trinkets at Haagen’s.

4. Letter to my father.— My correspondence furnishes a constant employment.— Evening at a Comedie de Societé, by invitation of Madame Schimmelpenninck who performed in both plays herself. Le prejugé à la mode and le Cercle.— Souque and young Moliere performed with much spirit. The rest may be passed without remark. My brother went after the play to a dance at Madm: Schimmelpenninck’s. Excused myself.— Called at Mr: Scholten’s, where I found Mr: Bourne, who came from Amsterdam this morning and is obliged to return to-morrow.— He is going to America.— Visit this morning from Mr: Luzac of Leyden.— Conversation with him.

5. Mr: Bourne breakfasted with us. At ten we took a Yacht for Rotterdam in company with Count Loewenhielm. M. de St: Laurent, General Rewbell, Mr: Euler, and Bielfeld—arrived between two and three. Dined with Mr: Bickercarton, the Swedish Consul at Rotterdam.— Company besides our party Mr: Crawford, Mr: Beeldemaker, Sir Robert Barclay, Mr: Walker and two or three other Gentlemen. Returned to the Hague in the Evening with the addition of Sir Robert.— The party very pleasant and agreeable.

6. As the day, was past yesterday in amusement, this was devoted to more than a common industry in writing.— Excepting a short walk, passed it altogether in writing, and added the Evening to the labour of the day.

7. Finished the second & began the third book of the History of Tacitus. Mr: Levsen called on me. We took a walk to Ryswick together.— Conversation upon the situation of our affairs with France. He told me they were trying the same experiment at Copenhagen as at Philadelphia, and would certainly not succeed— Evening at the french Comedy. Pierre le Grand, ou l’Empereur Charpentier, and Le Claveçin. both musical plays. The first, of Gretri’s composition, but not in his beat manner. performance somewhat dull.

8. Another busy day. Walk however before dinner, alone. Evening at Count Loewenhielm’s. Mm: Cneiff. M: de St: Laurent, General Rewbell and Bielfeld.— Play’d Whist. The Count gave us a general invitation for every Wednesday Evening, during the rest of the Season.
9. Busied so as only to have time for a short walk. Evening; at Mr: Noël’s party. Whist with Mr: Goldberg. Mr: Van Leyden and Mr: Bogaert. Conversation afterwards with Mr: Goldberg.
10. Madam Dumas died very suddenly last night.— Letter to Pitcairn.— Evening at Madam Cneiff’s. Unlucky as usual at whist.
11. Walk in the wood.— Evening at Mr: Bicker’s. Very large party. Quadrill with Madam Schimmelpenninck, Mr De Sitter & Mr —— I am tired of spending so much time at cards.

12. Letter this morning from London. All the morning till dinner time answering it. finished after dinner. Lost my walk, though the weather was very fine— Evening at Madam Cneiff’s.— Whist with indifferent luck. Madam put out of humour by an unexpected and unpleasant visitant.

13. Find myself somewhat relieved from the pressure of correspondence under which I have for some time laboured. Writing more leisurely— Visit from Mr: Epaphras Jones of New-York, R. Skinner, and another American. Went with them to the Assembly.— Visit from Bielfeld, and walk with him.— At the french Play in the Evening. Les deux Suisses.— Le Directeur dans l’Embarras.— Music of Cimarosa and of course excellent.

14. Mr: Schermerhorn called here in the forenoon. Mentioned Greenleaf’s failure. Visit of Mr: Levsen. Long walk with him.— Ball this Evening.— Visit to Madam Veerman, found her and her brother, Loder, in affliction for the Death of her mother.
15. Find a little leisure. Wrote to J. Gardner. Walk beyond Ryswick. Evening at Count Loewenhielm’s party.— Whist with indifferent luck.— Party not numerous.
16. Letter to my father.— Walk in the forenoon.— Evening at Madame Cneiff’s. Count Loewenhielm, much disposed not to believe the taking of Mantua. Disbelief is more easy than useful.— Played whist.

17. Bielfeld called on me, and walk with him before dinner.— Our opinions widen so continually from each other, that there is no longer the former cordiality between us.— Evening at home. finished reading the Idler. read likewise part of Murphy’s Essay on the life and Genius of Johnson. Rather superficial but entertaining.— Unconquerable indolence.—

18. Fine weather— Long walk before dinner with Mr: Levsen.— Told me our old Polish friend Midleton was dead— Peace to his shade!— Finished Murphy’s Essay. Abuses Sir John Hawkins for abusing Johnson.— Evening at Madam Hahn’s party.— Company numerous.— Quadrill with Mm: Toelaer, Mlle: Bicker and Bielfeld.

19. Another beautiful day. Walk before dinner.— Reading Blair’s Lectures upon Rhetoric and Belles Lettres.— Evening at Mr: Moliere’s. A family party.— Madam Labouchere.— Told me of her sons marriage with Sir F. Baring’s daughter.— Quadrill.— Supper and late home.

20. Fourth fine day.— Walk in the wood.— Dined at Mr: Noël’s. Remarkably civil, which generally indicates something bad from the french Government.— Conversation with Mr: Van Leyden.— Madame de Schubart told me she was determined to quit this Country.— Going first into Switzerland and thence to Spain.— Play’d Reversi, part of the Evening, with Madam d’Anduaga, Mr: Noel & General Rewbell.

21. Fifth steady fair day. A phenomenon in this Country at any season. At this time of the year almost a prodigy. Walk in the morning, as usual beyond Ryswick. Customary reading and writing. Evening at Madam Veerman’s.

22. Mr: Jones and Mr: Skinner called on me again this morning. Gave the former his certificate; and went with him to Mr: Noël’s, to procure one also from him which he gave.— First day of leisure from my letter-writing.— Read somewhat in the forenoon— Usual walk. Weather still remarkably fine. Evening at Count Lowenhielm’s. Whist with Madam May, M. de Martilly and Bielfeld.

23. Writing to my father.— Walk before dinner.— Weather still fine— Evening at Mr: Noël’s party. Remarkably civil; which implies something mischievous. Reversi with Mlle: Bogaert, Mr: d’Anduaga and General van der Meulen.

24. Messrs: Rutgers, Boers, Lawrence and Welch called here in the forenoon. They went down to the Helder, to go from thence to England, in Company with Mr: Bourne a week ago. But being wearied by a long continuance of contrary winds, they have concluded to go round by the way of Calais. Went with them to the Assembly to hear the debates. Furnished them with Passports, and a recommendation to Mr: Noël for a visa, to carry them into France.— Evening at Madam Cneiff’s. Whist with her M. de Chestret and Reuterswerd.

25. Visit from Mr: Levsen and walk with him round by the East India way. Told me of Baron de Schubart’s intention to quit this country.— Goes first into Switzerland, and probably afterwards as Danish Minister to Spain.— Levsen has also requested his dismission. Says he is tired of the diplomatic career.— Evening at Madam Cneiff’s. Large party— Whist with her Mlle: Laurenzi, and Mr: Bosset.
26. Letter to England.— Walk to Ryswick. Weather has returned to its customary dulness— Called in the Evening at Mr: Veerman’s. Madam is quite unwell.

27. Find myself at leisure for the moment from my correspondence; and consequently commenced this morning a speculation, which will doubtless soon add one more to my hundreds and hundreds of former abortive schemes.— Evening at Mlle: Laurenzi’s. Quadrill with Mm: Bosset, Mr: Mersen, and a Baron van der Hoop.— Health indifferent and bad nights.

28. Another day at length at my own disposal. Received my books from Paris. The Rousseau complete. My collection of the french classics has now no material deficiency.— Walk before dinner. Evening at Mr Veermans. Madam is better.— Unwell myself with a sore throat.

Day. Rise at about 7. Translate two pages from Tacitus before breakfast. Consulting constantly the commentaries of Brotier, Ernesti, and Ryckius, but no translation whatever— After breakfast, dress, and write letters or attend to other business till after two. Sometimes though rarely find time for a little desultory or occasional reading. Walk about an hour. Dine between three and four.— Read a couple of Blair’s Lectures— Spend almost every evening in company and at Cards. This is the part of the day, the most dissatisfactory to my judgment, but I fear some such relaxation is absolutely necessary to my health. During the first part of the Winter, I passed almost every Evening at home, and in close study upon a dead Language. My progress in it is not encouraging, and I could not support the continual tension of mind that it requires. Three morning hours I still devote not merely to the Latin, but to the greatest of Historians. I wish I could observe an encreasing facility to understand him— It is indeed my design to make myself perfect master of all the remains of this incomparable author. This alone is no trivial undertaking; and I know not whether the course of my life will allow me to complete it. The labour is not without its reward as it goes along. The profound knowledge of mankind, the energy and acuteness of sentiment The clearness of narration, the nice discrimination of characters, and the ardent spirit of freedom which appear in every line of the writer, relieve the fatigue of application to render his thoughts, and afford some consolation for the mortification continually returning of finding myself altogether unable to do them justice in a translation.
